articles.headline: After Years of Failure, California Lawmakers Pave the Way for More Housing
articles.snippet: To ease an affordability crisis, the Legislature voted to open suburbs to development, allowing two-units on lots long reserved for single-family homes.
articles.abstract: To ease an affordability crisis, the Legislature voted to open suburbs to development, allowing two-units on lots long reserved for single-family homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: California needs more housing. More condominiums, more townhouses near mass transit, more suburban apartment buildings. There is no other solution to the state’s desperate homelessness problem and a deepening housing affordability crisis, according to a broad collection of economists and housing experts.

articles.headline: Suicide Bombers in Kabul Kill Dozens, Including 13 U.S. Troops
articles.snippet: Bombers struck a huge crowd outside the airport, killing at least 60 Afghan civilians in the waning days of the U.S. evacuation from Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Bombers struck a huge crowd outside the airport, killing at least 60 Afghan civilians in the waning days of the U.S. evacuation from Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two explosions killed dozens of people, including at least 13 U.S. troops, ripping through the crowds outside Afghanistan’s main airport on Thursday, just hours after Western governments had warned of an imminent Islamic State attack and told their people to stay away from the airport.
articles.byline: By Matthieu Aikins, Sharif Hassan, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: After Decades of War, ISIS and Al Qaeda Can Still Wreak Havoc
articles.snippet: The U.S. and its allies waged war for 20 years to try to defeat terrorists in Afghanistan. A double-suicide bombing demonstrated that they remain a threat.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and its allies waged war for 20 years to try to defeat terrorists in Afghanistan. A double-suicide bombing demonstrated that they remain a threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — The nightmare that kept counterterrorism experts awake even before the Taliban returned to power is that Afghanistan would become fertile ground for terrorist groups, most notably Al Qaeda and the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Eric Schmitt and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Biden Faces a Tragedy He Pledged to Avoid
articles.snippet: The president said the evacuation of U.S. citizens and allies from Afghanistan would continue, even after an attack that killed at least 13 American troops and dozens of civilians.
articles.abstract: The president said the evacuation of U.S. citizens and allies from Afghanistan would continue, even after an attack that killed at least 13 American troops and dozens of civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was exactly what President Biden feared most.

articles.headline: Lake Tahoe Suffocates With Smoke
articles.snippet: Smoke from the Caldor fire is overwhelming one of California’s most iconic regions — and confounding thousands of newcomers who fled there in recent months to escape the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Smoke from the Caldor fire is overwhelming one of California’s most iconic regions — and confounding thousands of newcomers who fled there in recent months to escape the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAHOE CITY, Calif. — When the pandemic swept through California last year, Lake Tahoe, the azure gem of the Sierra Nevada, swarmed with city dwellers fleeing to the purity of its alpine air.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: Calls Grow to Discipline Doctors Spreading Virus Misinformation
articles.snippet: A tiny number of doctors have had an outsize influence in spreading false information about Covid-19 and vaccines.
articles.abstract: A tiny number of doctors have had an outsize influence in spreading false information about Covid-19 and vaccines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing before a local school board in central Indiana this month, Dr. Daniel Stock, a physician in the state, issued a litany of false claims about the coronavirus. He proclaimed that the recent surge in cases showed that the vaccines were ineffective, that people were better off with a cocktail of drugs and supplements to prevent hospitalization from the virus, and that masks didn’t help prevent the spread of infection.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: The Rise and Fall of the World’s Ride-Hailing Giant
articles.snippet: Didi pushed the limits and thrived in legal gray areas. Until China cracked down.
articles.abstract: Didi pushed the limits and thrived in legal gray areas. Until China cracked down.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s leading ride-hailing company, Didi, was an operation of dubious legality when it raised its first big bucket of money nearly a decade ago. And in one way or another, it has been testing the authorities ever since.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Li Yuan

articles.headline: Why Would an Economist Ever Look on the Bright Side?
articles.snippet: For Wall Street, and the dismal science as a whole, trouble is around every corner even as the economy booms.
articles.abstract: For Wall Street, and the dismal science as a whole, trouble is around every corner even as the economy booms.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s dismal scientists can paint even a blue-sky outlook gray.

articles.headline: How to Make Your Marriage More Financially Equal
articles.snippet: Whether you’re newlyweds or not, your marriage can only benefit from a better balance that eases the stress on both of you. But be ready to talk — “we” statements only, please.
articles.abstract: Whether you’re newlyweds or not, your marriage can only benefit from a better balance that eases the stress on both of you. But be ready to talk — “we” statements only, please.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year and a half of pandemic living has revealed — or reminded us of — some persistent patterns around money, gender, marriage and families. And they aren’t always pretty.

articles.headline: Powell Signals Federal Reserve Could Slow Bond Purchases This Year
articles.snippet: The Fed chair warned that the Delta variant remained a risk and suggested that a rate increase was not on the table for some time.
articles.abstract: The Fed chair warned that the Delta variant remained a risk and suggested that a rate increase was not on the table for some time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eighteen months into the pandemic, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, has offered the strongest sign yet that the Fed is prepared to soon withdraw one leg of the support it has been providing to the economy as conditions strengthen.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Madeleine Ngo

articles.headline: New York’s Private Schools Tackle White Privilege. It Has Not Been Easy.
articles.snippet: In this world — where tuition runs as high as $58,000 — the topic has become flammable. Parents, faculty, students and alumni have all entered the fray.
articles.abstract: In this world — where tuition runs as high as $58,000 — the topic has become flammable. Parents, faculty, students and alumni have all entered the fray.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several years back Grace Church School, an elite private school in Manhattan, embraced an antiracist mission and sought to have students and teachers wrestle with whiteness, racial privilege and bias.
